annotator_prompt:
You are  70 years old, Heterosexual, Hispanic, Retired Professor, patient, analytical, calm, thoughtful, woman, with PhD education, and  intent. Context: . Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:.
logs: @GoldenYears66: I understand where you're coming from, but I gotta disagree with that statement. It's not all men who are sex offenders. There are plenty of good men out there who respect women and don't engage in such behavior. We need to focus on the individuals who commit these crimes rather than generalizing an entire gender.

@TechGuru88: I agree with @GoldenYears66, we should not generalize
all men as sex offenders. That's unfair and inaccurate. It's like
saying all women are nagging or all men are lazy. We need to focus
on the individuals who commit these crimes rather than stereotyping
an entire gender. Furthermore, it's important to recognize that
most sexual assaults are committed by people known to the victim,
not strangers. This highlights the importance of building healthy
relationships and trust with others.

@QueenOfChaos: Oh please, spare me the "we need to focus on individuals" nonsense. You're just trying to downplay the fact that men are disproportionately represented in sex offender statistics. And don't even get me started on your "healthy relationships and trust" comment. That's just a way of saying "women should just be grateful they're not being assaulted by strangers." Newsflash, @TechGuru88: most women are already aware of the risks of sexual assault, but that doesn't mean we should have to live in fear of our own shadows.

I am 66 years old, and I have lived through many changes in society. I must say that I find it quite disturbing to see how some people are trying to generalize all men as sex offenders. It is unfair and unjust to make such sweeping statements. @QueenOfChaos, you mentioned that men are disproportionately represented in sex offender statistics. That may be true, but we should not forget that there are many good men out there who do not engage in such behavior. We must also consider the fact that women can also commit sexual offenses and that they are underrepresented in these statistics.

I'm glad someone finally spoke some sense around here! @GoldenYears66,
you're absolutely right. We can't just generalize all men as sex
offenders based on statistics. And I agree that women can also be
perpetrators of sexual offenses, but let's not forget the power dynamic
at play here. Men have historically held more power and control over
women, which makes them more likely to commit these crimes. It's not
about hating men or healthy sex; it's about acknowledging the reality
of this issue and working towards a more equitable society.

I'm glad someone finally agrees with me! @QueenOfChaos, I couldn't have said it better myself. And I love how you brought up the power dynamic. It's so true that men have historically held more power over women, which is why we see these statistics. But let's not forget that this isn't just about sex crimes; it's about all forms of oppression and inequality.

I must respectfully disagree with the notion that all men are sex offenders. Such a blanket statement is not only inaccurate but also harmful. It perpetuates harmful stereotypes and stigmatizes an entire gender based on the actions of a few individuals. Furthermore, it ignores the fact that most men do not engage in sexual violence or harassment.

Furthermore, it ignores the fact that most men do not engage in sexual violence or harassment.
